title: How to Make Banana Cupcakes

methods.name:
Making the Banana Cupcakes[5]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375ºF (190ºC).
steps.description: Either use silicone cupcake cases on their own, or paper cupcake cases in a muffin pan (this helps to hold their shape best).

steps.headline: Beat together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
steps.description: You can do this using handheld mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks.

steps.headline: Add the eggs, one at a time.
steps.description: Mix the butter mixture well after each egg that you add.

steps.headline: Mix in the bananas and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Peel, slice, and mash the bananas first, then add them to the butter mixture. The more ripe your bananas are, the better. If you like chocolate, consider adding 1 cup (175 grams) of semi-sweet chocolate chips.

steps.headline: Sift together the flour, baking powder, and baking soda in a separate bowl.
steps.description: To add more flavor to your cupcakes, add ¼ teaspoon of ground nutmeg or ½ teaspoon of ground cinnamon.

steps.headline: Add the flour mixture and buttermilk to the butter mixture a little bit at a time.
steps.description: Alternate between the two, and mix well after each one. You can also use ½ to ¾ cup (125 to 190 grams) of plain or vanilla yogurt instead of buttermilk.

steps.headline: Fill the cupcake liners two-thirds of the way with the batter.
steps.description: Line a cupcake pan with some paper cupcake liners first, then use a spoon or ice cream scoop to fill them. You can also use silicone cupcake liners instead; place them on a baking sheet.

steps.headline: Bake on the middle rack for 18 to 22 minutes.
steps.description: The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the center of a cupcake comes out clean.

steps.headline: Let the cupcakes cool.
steps.description: Allow them to cool for 10 minutes first, then remove them from the pan, and set them down on a cooling rack. Let them finish cooling the rest of the way before continuing.

steps.headline: Frost the cupcakes with your favorite frosting.
steps.description: Good combinations with banana for the frosting flavor include: chocolate, peanut butter, and vanilla. You can spread the frosting onto the cupcakes using a spatula, or you can pipe them on using a piping bag. If you don't have a favorite frosting recipe, you can choose one from below.

steps.headline: Cream the butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.
steps.description: You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles. To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into cubes first.

steps.headline: Sift together the sugar and cocoa powder and set aside.
steps.description: Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps. This will ensure that your frosting is nice and smooth.

steps.headline: Whisk together the heavy cream and vanilla extract.
steps.description: If you don't have heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead. Make sure that the vanilla is evenly distributed throughout the heavy cream.

steps.headline: Slowly mix in the sugar mixture and heavy cream mixture into the butter.
steps.description: Alternate between the sugar and heavy cream, and beat on low speed after adding each one.

steps.headline: Beat on high speed until the frosting is light and creamy, about 2 minutes.
steps.description: Give the frosting a taste. If it is too sweet for you, add a pinch of salt, and mix again. If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream. If it is too thin, add some more sugar.

steps.headline: Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
steps.description: Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt. You can spread it on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle.

steps.headline: Cream the peanut butter and butter until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes.
steps.description: You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Be sure to use a medium speed setting.

steps.headline: Add the confectioners' sugar and vanilla extract, and mix again using a medium speed setting.
steps.description: Keep mixing until the sugar and vanilla are evenly distributed throughout the butter mixture. There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls.

steps.headline: Pour in the heavy cream and mix on high until creamy, about 2 minutes.
steps.description: If you don't have any heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead. Give the frosting a taste; if it is too sweet, add a pinch of salt and mix again. If it is too thin, add some more sugar. If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream.

steps.headline: Frost the cupcakes.
steps.description: Once the cupcakes have completely cooled, you can spread the frosting on top using a spatula, or pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's tip. For an added touch, sprinkle the cupcakes with some mini chocolate chips.

steps.headline: Cream together the cream cheese and butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.
steps.description: You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles. To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into small cubes first.

steps.headline: Beat in the milk and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Keep mixing until both are evenly distributed throughout the cream cheese and butter mixture. There should be no streaks or swirls.

steps.headline: Slowly mix in the confectioners' sugar until the frosting is smooth.
steps.description: If the frosting is too thin, add in some more sugar. If the frosting is too thick, add some more milk. Mix well after each addition. You may not end up using all 3 cups (375 grams) of confectioners' sugar.

steps.headline: Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
steps.description: Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt. You can spread the frosting on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle. For a final touch, consider sprinkling the finished cupcakes with a light dusting of cinnamon, cocoa powder, or nutmeg.

text:
Making the Banana Cupcakes[5]
	X
		Research source Preheat the oven to 375ºF (190ºC). Either use silicone cupcake cases on their own, or paper cupcake cases in a muffin pan (this helps to hold their shape best). Beat together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. You can do this using handheld mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks. Add the eggs, one at a time. Mix the butter mixture well after each egg that you add. Mix in the bananas and vanilla extract. Peel, slice, and mash the bananas first, then add them to the butter mixture. The more ripe your bananas are, the better. If you like chocolate, consider adding 1 cup (175 grams) of semi-sweet chocolate chips. Sift together the flour, baking powder, and baking soda in a separate bowl. To add more flavor to your cupcakes, add ¼ teaspoon of ground nutmeg or ½ teaspoon of ground cinnamon. Add the flour mixture and buttermilk to the butter mixture a little bit at a time. Alternate between the two, and mix well after each one. You can also use ½ to ¾ cup (125 to 190 grams) of plain or vanilla yogurt instead of buttermilk. Fill the cupcake liners two-thirds of the way with the batter. Line a cupcake pan with some paper cupcake liners first, then use a spoon or ice cream scoop to fill them. You can also use silicone cupcake liners instead; place them on a baking sheet. Bake on the middle rack for 18 to 22 minutes. The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the center of a cupcake comes out clean. Let the cupcakes cool. Allow them to cool for 10 minutes first, then remove them from the pan, and set them down on a cooling rack. Let them finish cooling the rest of the way before continuing. Frost the cupcakes with your favorite frosting. Good combinations with banana for the frosting flavor include: chocolate, peanut butter, and vanilla. You can spread the frosting onto the cupcakes using a spatula, or you can pipe them on using a piping bag. If you don't have a favorite frosting recipe, you can choose one from below. Making Milk Chocolate Frosting Cream the butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes. You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles. To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into cubes first. Sift together the sugar and cocoa powder and set aside. Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps. This will ensure that your frosting is nice and smooth. Whisk together the heavy cream and vanilla extract. If you don't have heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead. Make sure that the vanilla is evenly distributed throughout the heavy cream. Slowly mix in the sugar mixture and heavy cream mixture into the butter. Alternate between the sugar and heavy cream, and beat on low speed after adding each one. Beat on high speed until the frosting is light and creamy, about 2 minutes. Give the frosting a taste. If it is too sweet for you, add a pinch of salt, and mix again. If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream. If it is too thin, add some more sugar. Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes. Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt. You can spread it on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle. Making Peanut Butter Frosting Cream the peanut butter and butter until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. Be sure to use a medium speed setting. Add the confectioners' sugar and vanilla extract, and mix again using a medium speed setting. Keep mixing until the sugar and vanilla are evenly distributed throughout the butter mixture. There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls. Pour in the heavy cream and mix on high until creamy, about 2 minutes. If you don't have any heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead. Give the frosting a taste; if it is too sweet, add a pinch of salt and mix again. If it is too thin, add some more sugar. If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream. Frost the cupcakes. Once the cupcakes have completely cooled, you can spread the frosting on top using a spatula, or pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's tip. For an added touch, sprinkle the cupcakes with some mini chocolate chips. Making Vanilla Cream Cheese Frosting Cream together the cream cheese and butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes. You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles. To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into small cubes first. Beat in the milk and vanilla extract. Keep mixing until both are evenly distributed throughout the cream cheese and butter mixture. There should be no streaks or swirls. Slowly mix in the confectioners' sugar until the frosting is smooth. If the frosting is too thin, add in some more sugar. If the frosting is too thick, add some more milk. Mix well after each addition. You may not end up using all 3 cups (375 grams) of confectioners' sugar. Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes. Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt. You can spread the frosting on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle. For a final touch, consider sprinkling the finished cupcakes with a light dusting of cinnamon, cocoa powder, or nutmeg.
sentences:
Making the Banana Cupcakes[5]
	X
		Research source Preheat the oven to 375ºF (190ºC).
Either use silicone cupcake cases on their own, or paper cupcake cases in a muffin pan (this helps to hold their shape best).
Beat together the butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
You can do this using handheld mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks.
Add the eggs, one at a time.
Mix the butter mixture well after each egg that you add.
Mix in the bananas and vanilla extract.
Peel, slice, and mash the bananas first, then add them to the butter mixture.
The more ripe your bananas are, the better.
If you like chocolate, consider adding 1 cup (175 grams) of semi-sweet chocolate chips.
Sift together the flour, baking powder, and baking soda in a separate bowl.
To add more flavor to your cupcakes, add ¼ teaspoon of ground nutmeg or ½ teaspoon of ground cinnamon.
Add the flour mixture and buttermilk to the butter mixture a little bit at a time.
Alternate between the two, and mix well after each one.
You can also use ½ to ¾ cup (125 to 190 grams) of plain or vanilla yogurt instead of buttermilk.
Fill the cupcake liners two-thirds of the way with the batter.
Line a cupcake pan with some paper cupcake liners first, then use a spoon or ice cream scoop to fill them.
You can also use silicone cupcake liners instead; place them on a baking sheet.
Bake on the middle rack for 18 to 22 minutes.
The cupcakes are ready when a toothpick inserted into the center of a cupcake comes out clean.
Let the cupcakes cool.
Allow them to cool for 10 minutes first, then remove them from the pan, and set them down on a cooling rack.
Let them finish cooling the rest of the way before continuing.
Frost the cupcakes with your favorite frosting.
Good combinations with banana for the frosting flavor include: chocolate, peanut butter, and vanilla.
You can spread the frosting onto the cupcakes using a spatula, or you can pipe them on using a piping bag.
If you don't have a favorite frosting recipe, you can choose one from below.
Making Milk Chocolate Frosting Cream the butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.
You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles.
To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into cubes first.
Sift together the sugar and cocoa powder and set aside.
Make sure that there are no lumps or clumps.
This will ensure that your frosting is nice and smooth.
Whisk together the heavy cream and vanilla extract.
If you don't have heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead.
Make sure that the vanilla is evenly distributed throughout the heavy cream.
Slowly mix in the sugar mixture and heavy cream mixture into the butter.
Alternate between the sugar and heavy cream, and beat on low speed after adding each one.
Beat on high speed until the frosting is light and creamy, about 2 minutes.
Give the frosting a taste.
If it is too sweet for you, add a pinch of salt, and mix again.
If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream.
If it is too thin, add some more sugar.
Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt.
You can spread it on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle.
Making Peanut Butter Frosting Cream the peanut butter and butter until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes.
You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with a paddle attachment.
Be sure to use a medium speed setting.
Add the confectioners' sugar and vanilla extract, and mix again using a medium speed setting.
Keep mixing until the sugar and vanilla are evenly distributed throughout the butter mixture.
There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls.
Pour in the heavy cream and mix on high until creamy, about 2 minutes.
If you don't have any heavy cream, you can use half-and-half instead.
Give the frosting a taste; if it is too sweet, add a pinch of salt and mix again.
If it is too thin, add some more sugar.
If it is too thick, add some more heavy cream.
Frost the cupcakes.
Once the cupcakes have completely cooled, you can spread the frosting on top using a spatula, or pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's tip.
For an added touch, sprinkle the cupcakes with some mini chocolate chips.
Making Vanilla Cream Cheese Frosting Cream together the cream cheese and butter until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes.
You can do this using a handheld mixer or an electric mixer fitted with paddles.
To make the mixing even easier, cut the butter into small cubes first.
Beat in the milk and vanilla extract.
Keep mixing until both are evenly distributed throughout the cream cheese and butter mixture.
There should be no streaks or swirls.
Slowly mix in the confectioners' sugar until the frosting is smooth.
If the frosting is too thin, add in some more sugar.
If the frosting is too thick, add some more milk.
Mix well after each addition.
You may not end up using all 3 cups (375 grams) of confectioners' sugar.
Spread or pipe the frosting onto the cupcakes.
Make sure that the cupcakes are completely cool first, or the frosting will melt.
You can spread the frosting on using a spatula, or you can pipe it on using a piping bag and decorator's nozzle.
For a final touch, consider sprinkling the finished cupcakes with a light dusting of cinnamon, cocoa powder, or nutmeg.
tyn_section: baking sheet and silicone cupcake liners
